title: The 'Self-Care' Initiative: Mechanisms of Engaging Patients and the Socio-Cultural Implications
abstractText:
Tackling chronic disease is important because it is one of the leading causes of death in the UK. This places an extraordinary burden on the NHS, informal carers and the wider economy. Consequently, ‘expert patient’ initiatives (ie, managing one’s own illness through self-care) have emerged in efforts to make health care more cost-efficient and to improve health. Greater participation in self-care may help to increase patient’s confidence in managing their condition and their overall well-being. These beneficial outcomes stress the importance of providing information in an effective manner so that patients can understand it and apply the knowledge to help manage their condition more effectively.

Poor communication and lack of understanding are key barriers to patients becoming active in their care. It is widely acknowledged that there is not a lack of information about healthy lifestyles but rather the manner of communication of risk and the level of support for lifestyle change often need improvement. This seminar series brings multi-disciplinary researchers and health care professionals together to examine effective mechanisms of engaging patients in self-care, while considering that barriers and inequalities may exist. These seminars will also address any gaps that exist between patients and health providers.
